thread.title: Joel Thompson says it’s time for Australia to unite amid national anthem debate
thread.title_full: Joel Thompson says it’s time for Australia to unite amid national anthem debate | Daily Telegraph

author: Paul Crawley
title: Joel Thompson says it’s time for Australia to unite amid national anthem debate
text:
HE is one of the proudest and most respected indigenous role models in the NRL today.
But out of respect to “the people who have served our country and the people who have died for us as a nation”, tough Dragons backrower Joel Thompson won’t be following Anthony Mundine’s lead at Friday night’s All Stars match in Newcastle.
Mundine last week sparked a national controversy when he refused to stand for the Australian national anthem ahead of his blockbuster fight with Danny Green.
Mundine labelled it “a racist anthem” and said it “doesn’t represent our people”.
That forced organisers to play the anthem sung by fellow indigenous star Jessica Mauboy before the fighters entered the ring in Adelaide.
media_camera Anthony Mundine sparked a national controversy last week.
Mundine stated prior to the fight: “I’m not trying to divide people or be controversial but you’ve asked the question and I’m answering it honestly to tell people where I stand. We’re not young and free.
“My people are still being oppressed. Nothing’s changed ... the anthem isn’t right. It’s not for all of Australia. I just can’t stand up for something I don’t believe in.”
While Thompson said he understood both sides of the argument, he declared “it is time for us as a nation to unite and come together”.
Thompson did not want to comment on whether the anthem should change.
“That is someone else’s decision,” he said.
media_camera Joel Thompson understands both sides of the national anthem argument
“I respect everyone’s opinion. I think it is time for us as a nation to unite and come together. There is so much divide across Australia.
“I can understand where Choc is coming from and I respect his opinion. I can definitely understand what he is talking about.
“If people actually did research into the song and when the song was written, people are still hurt by what happened. But everyone has their own opinion on it.
“I think it is time that we stand together and make some decisions where we can unite.
“I respect the anthem and what it represents for me as a person. For the people who have served our country and the people who have died for us as a nation. I understand both sides.”
media_camera The NRL World All Stars and NRL indigenous All Stars during a team photo in Sydney. Picture: Brett Costello
Thompson had a difficult childhood but after a troubled start to his NRL career he has used his experiences to help mentor and inspire young indigenous people facing similar challenges.
“There is so much divide and it isn’t hard to see it,” he said.
“You see it on social media, you see a lot of divide. I think it is time to fight all the issues as one.”
He said to be selected in the Indigenous All Stars “means a lot”.
“Not just to me but my family and what it represents,” he said.
Meanwhile, Canberra’s Jarrod Croker, Gold Coast’s Chris McQueen and Cronulla’s Gerard Beale have been called into the World All Stars squad.
The trio will replace Joseph Leilua, Jarryd Hayne and Sosaia Feki, who were ruled out through injury.
